山地摄影：拍摄令人惊叹的图像的 20 个技巧和技巧一文首先出现在《数码摄影学校》上。它的作者是约翰·麦金泰尔。

本文于 2023 年 12 月更新，由 John McIntire、 David Shaw 、 Gavin Hardcastle和Kav Dadfar贡献。

锯齿状的山峰、陡峭的山坡、深邃而广阔的山谷：山脉无疑是地球上最上镜的拍摄对象之一。它也表明——查看任何摄影杂志或网站，你可能会发现不只是一两张而是几十张山的照片。

尽管山脉看起来令人惊叹，但拍摄令人惊叹的山脉照片（充分体现其宏伟和力量的那种）可能很困难。幸运的是，你不是一个人！

下面，我们分享了许多建议，将您的山地摄影从零提升为英雄，包括我对装备、天气、灯光等的想法。我们还深入研究高山湖泊摄影——这样您就可以将大自然中最华丽的两种元素结合起来， 制作出专业级的风景照片。

由于每个技巧都来自该领域的直接经验，因此您可以确信它值得您花时间！

准备好下次追山时获得更好的结果了吗？让我们开始吧。

1.利用光线

灯光可能是成功的山地照片最重要的一个方面。虽然背光和前光在某些情况下都可以工作，但山脉在侧光下茁壮成长。侧面的光线凸显出山脊、悬崖和起伏斜坡的阴影和细节。它提供了对比和戏剧性。

大风景（如山脉）的图像依赖自然光进行照明，因此您可以随心所欲地拍摄天气。阴天会使光线变平，而正午的阳光会淹没阴影，将令人愉悦的对比变成令人眯眼的白色和黑色。这些具有挑战性的场景可以产生成功的图像，但低角度侧光（即黄金时段景观照明）使我们作为摄影师的生活变得更加轻松。

2. 小心地放置你的地平线

你的地平线是照片中最重要的部分之一。考虑一下三分法——除非你有充分的理由这样做！ – 避免将地平线置于画面中间。

如果场景有一个有趣的前景和/或一个无趣的天空（即白云或纯净、平坦的蓝色），请将地平线放在画面的高处。

或者，如果您面对有趣的云层和/或相对无特色的前景，您可以将地平线放低以显示更多的天空。

3.填充框架

山脉本质上是巨大的。您不必将整个事物放入框架中。用某种吸引你注意力的元素填充框架也是可以接受的。这将使山成为图像中的背景。

是的，尝试在画面中获得巨大的远景可能很诱人。但如果你花点时间寻找可以拍出有趣照片的小细节，你可能会发现一些意想不到的东西。

4. 用较小的元素显示比例

同样，山脉往往很大，但当你用超广角镜头拍摄时，你最终会把视角推后。这使得观众很难真正了解画面中物体的大小。

您可以通过添加一个显示场景中事物比例的元素来解决这个问题。建筑物、人和动物都运转良好。

5. 将人物纳入风景中

与上一点一样，将人物放入山地风景摄影中可以传达山有多大。

然而，它的作用还不止于此！通过加入人为元素，您可以添加一些可以让观众产生共鸣的东西。

6.不要忘记颜色

鲜艳的色彩吸引眼球。在山的图像中尤其如此。日落和日出、色彩缤纷的前景和明亮的蓝色高山天空将有助于吸引并保持观看者的目光。

这与第一个山地摄影技巧（关于使用光线！）非常吻合。良好的光线通常等同于良好的色彩。光线质量越好，场景的颜色就越鲜艳。得到一个，你通常会得到另一个。

这并不是说图像必须具有明亮的色彩才能成功。低饱和度的图像可能会情绪低落、令人沉思。暴风雨的天空和冬季场景是颜色可能不丰富但不会损害最终图像的两个例子。此类照片的繁荣在于场景的戏剧性，而不是色彩。

黑白图像中完全没有色彩，但可以将山脉描绘得非常美丽。在此类图像中，对比度和情绪起着更重要的作用。

关于黑白山地摄影的注意事项：当光线和颜色等因素不利于您时，黑白转换通常是一个很好的工具。我在平光下拍摄了许多图像，这些图像可以很好地转换为黑白图像，尽管彩色图像暗淡无光。

7.尝试全景

当您拍摄山脉时，不要害怕拍摄一系​​列可以拼接在一起形成全景的照片。

山脉往往特别适合全景格式，因为有太多可看的东西！

8. 填充你的前景

这可能是标准的风景摄影建议，但在拍摄山脉时仍然适用。如果您使用广角镜头，前景中将有足够的空间 - 您需要用一些有趣的东西来填充它。

因此，选择一个前景主题并靠近它。这可以是花朵、有趣的岩层，或者简单的东西，比如标志。

然后拍摄一张结合了有趣的前景和美丽的山脉背景的照片，如下所示：

9. 纳入人为因素

我所说的人为因素，并不是指人。相反，我建议您找到一些人造的东西，向您的观众展示住在附近的人们如何将这座山融入他们的生活。

山脉本身就令人印象深刻。但作为我们世界的一部分，它们也是我们生活的一部分。如果你能在你的图像中展示这一点，你也许能够传达一个有趣的故事。

10.尝试并置

并置是指彼此相对放置的对比元素。在摄影中，这种对比可以是视觉上的——明暗对比、明亮与柔和的颜色、暖色与冷色——也可以是概念上的对比主题。

根据我的经验，所有这些都是山地摄影的重要组成部分！

并置的色调以有趣的方式组合在一起。山景，尤其是落基山脉、喀斯喀特山脉或阿拉斯加等地的山景，往往以冷色调为主：蓝色的天空、绿色的苔原和森林、冰川溪流和清澈的蓝色湖泊。当黄色、红色或粉色等暖色调融入场景中时，这些冷色调的场景通常看起来更好。通常，暖色调最好呈现为闪光的色彩——夕阳、野花或徒步旅行者的明亮夹克——而不是等同于冷色调。

（当一个场景中冷色调和暖色调都占主导地位时，你的大脑将很难区分出应该注意哪一个，令人愉悦的并置将变成一堆冲突的颜色。）

但对我来说，主题并置才是风景图像变得生动的地方。当谈到山脉时，基于主题的对比有很大的潜力。

一些对比鲜明的山地照片，例如下图大弯国家公园沙漠山脉上空的彩虹，有明显的主题并置（雨与干燥的沙漠岩石）。但同一图像在形状和纹理上也具有视觉对比（例如，锯齿状的岩石和彩虹的平滑曲线）。所有这些很好地结合在一起，以提供兴趣。

11.使用不同的焦点

在山地风景摄影中，山不需要成为图像的焦点。相反，您可以找到不同的焦点并使用山作为环境信息。

当然，您仍然可以拍摄一览无遗的景色。但完成后，将目光放小一些，看看场景中是否还有其他主题。

12. 纳入山地湖泊

在风景摄影中，湖泊和河流的倒影具有令人难以置信的吸引力，尤其是当周围是雄伟的雪山，在夕阳的照射下发出炽热的光芒时。因此，只要有可能，请尝试在您的照片中加入一个带有华丽倒影的高山湖泊！

拍摄令人惊叹的高山湖泊摄影的一些快速提示：

等风停

如果您在大风天外出，不要指望能拍到宁静的湖景。为了获得良好的反射效果，你需要让水完全静止。偶尔有一阵微风就好了，只要呆在附近等待风停就可以了。你只需要几分钟。带上一把露营椅和保温瓶，然后坐下来等待完美的时刻。它会来的。

使用偏光镜（并拍摄两个版本）

如果您在没有偏光镜的情况下拍摄湖景，您会得到可爱的镜面反射，但您可能会错过前景水下的一些有趣的细节。我喜欢用偏光镜在不同位置拍摄至少两张照片。一张照片会给我最大的反射，而另一张照片会减少反射以显示水下的细节。然后，我可以在 Photoshop 中轻松混合两种曝光，以获得反射和水细节的最佳组合。

调整你的角度

我喜欢选择山脉中最有趣的点，然后在前景中找到一个反映该有趣点的位置。我经常需要将相机靠近地面才能实现这一点，有时将三脚架调整到最低点。但有时，您可能不需要走得那么低，只需后退几英尺即可将倒影放置在您需要的位置。

您无法更改山的位置，但可以更改相对于山的位置以捕捉有趣的前景和倒影。

星星的倒影令人难以置信

如果您在平静、晴朗的夜晚拍摄，那么您就有机会在湖面倒影中捕捉银河或星轨。在其中放置一座巨大的山脉，你就获得了致命一击！

13. 使用 GND 滤波器

为了帮助您在现场获得良好的曝光，请不要忘记带上渐变中性密度滤光片。这些将使您在拍摄时均匀曝光，从而使您回家后更容易处理图像。

14.从不同角度拍摄

当您刚开始进行山地摄影时，很容易养成从同一角度一遍又一遍地拍摄的习惯 - 但只要有可能，我鼓励您将其混合起来！

虽然你可以从无数的角度和视角拍摄山脉，但我想重点关注三种主要方法：低角度、中山和高角度拍摄。请注意，这些因素不仅会极大地影响最终图像的外观，还会影响其情绪和感觉。

从谷底仰视拍摄的照片会使山脉显得高大而雄伟。这些低角度镜头为有趣的前景提供了空间，许多经典风景都是从这个角度拍摄的。虽然有效，但从谷底拍摄也有缺点。低视角意味着视野有限；没有一望无际的山峰海洋。照明通常很困难。山谷底部是早晨最后获得阳光的地方，也是晚上最先失去阳光的地方，因此平衡光线会使曝光变得棘手。当景观被均匀照亮时，黎明或黄昏的甜蜜光线将早已过去。

半山的拍摄非常壮观，可以看到山下和山上的景色。这个视角是我最喜欢的视角之一，它可以让景观有很大的深度，同时保持山脉的大小和戏剧性。

然而，拍摄精彩的高角度山景照片却很困难。从山顶拍摄的图像往往会使周围的景观看起来很小。我在山峰上拍摄过照片，所有的山脉看起来都像岩石波浪，而不是高耸的山峰。您可以通过在镜头中添加一个人来弥补这一点，这样可以提供比例，而且它可以将焦点从山脉上移开，并将其放在山中的人类体验上。人为因素会改变你的图像，使其不再是风景，而是更像肖像或动作镜头，但这种方法可能非常有效。

15.等待灯光

这个提示不能被低估。如果您想要拍摄出最美的山地风景摄影图像，请等待光线处于最佳状态。如果您很早就到达现场并找到了所需的构图，请不要害怕留下来直到光线变化 - 即使这需要几个小时。

是的，我知道这看起来很无聊，而且很难证明这种努力是合理的，但是请相信我。这是非常值得花时间和精力的。

16.使用更长的镜头

当您收拾行装准备去山里旅行时，别忘了带上长焦镜头。标准长度定焦镜头非常适合拍摄全景照片，但长焦镜头可以帮助您挑选场景中的较小细节。

换句话说：

除了在风景摄影中占据主导地位的广角镜头之外，镜头还有很大的空间。

17. 规划灯光

借助我们现有的技术，比以往任何时候都更容易准确地知道一年中任何一天的光线来自哪个方向。

因此，一旦您知道要去的时间和地点，请进行研究并找出太阳将在哪里升起或落下。然后根据这个计划你的拍摄！

18. 做好天气计划

就像规划光线一样，规划天气也是一个好主意。了解天气将帮助您确定是否需要携带任何额外的装备，例如防雨罩和防水服。

当然，了解何时可能出现雪或雨也符合人身安全的最佳利益。如果您打算去山上，尤其是在黄金时段之后，这一点就更为重要。

19.不要避开恶劣天气

虽然为恶劣天气做好准备是件好事，但您并不总是需要呆在室内。很多时候，最有趣的照片会在最糟糕的天气下出现。

事实上，我所见过的一些最好的光线是在暴风雨停歇时出现的。这些休息处提供了足够的光线，让一切看起来就像童话故事一样。

如果天气不好的时候把自己锁起来，你就永远不会经历这样的时刻。

20.注意安全

最重要的是，努力确保安全。山地风景摄影可能会带来难以置信的回报，但不要为了拍出精彩的照片而拿个人健康冒险。

注意您要去的地方，穿上适合天气的衣服，了解天气预报，并告诉别人您要去哪里。如果您要在外面呆到蓝色时间过后，请确保您确切知道如何返回。

山地风光摄影：最后的话

我希望这篇文章能够激励您走出去，创作自己的山地摄影。

下次您外出拍摄山脉时，请记住这些提示 - 并享受乐趣！

你以前拍过山吗？您有什么自己的秘诀吗？在下面的评论中分享吧！

山地摄影常见问题解答

哪种类型的镜头最适合山地摄影？

所有镜头都有其用途。广角镜头最受欢迎，但标准镜头和长焦镜头也可以使用。

一天中拍摄山脉的最佳时间是什么？

这完全取决于光线照射到山上的位置。只要太阳不在山后面，黄金时段就是最好的时间。

如何在照片中显示一座山有多大？

您可以添加一个易于观看者识别的元素，例如人。这会给你的图像带来规模感。

为什么我照片中的山看起来那么遥远？

广角镜头会扭曲视角，这会将所有东西推回到画面中。使用标准焦距（35mm 至 50mm）以获得接近人眼的视角。要在画面中包含更多内容，请考虑以全景格式拍摄。

引人注目的街头人像摄影的 18 个技巧首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是安东尼·埃佩斯。

本文于 2023 年 12 月更新，贡献者包括 Anthony Epes、Desmond Louw、 Andrew S. Gibson 、 Simon Bond 、 Kevin Landwer-Johan和Zuhair A. Al-Traifi 。

街头人像摄影非常有趣且有益，但捕捉精彩图像并不总是那么容易。您可能很难找到合适的拍摄对象和合适的构图，或者当您在街上经过人们时，您可能会对拍摄他们感到不舒服。

我喜欢拍摄街头肖像，在这篇文章中，我分享了所有我最喜欢的获得美丽效果的技巧和技巧。我将解释如何处理不同的背景、如何捕捉有趣的姿势以及如何接近人们以便快速捕捉镜头。完成后，您将准备好创建属于您自己的有趣且令人回味的图像。

因此，无论您是街头肖像初学者还是只是想提高现有技能，请继续阅读！

什么是街头肖像？

街头肖像显示了人的脸。可以在获得许可的情况下捕获它，但并非必须如此。当然，这是在街上拍摄的。

街头肖像有一种真实的元素。你不会带模特出去，如果你确实请求许可，你永远不知道你请求的人是否会同意让你拍照。

当然，如果您获得许可，您将能够控制镜头的许多元素。您可以要求拍摄对象站在有趣的背景前，将脸转向光源，或控制他们的面部表情。

但如何创作出出色的街头肖像呢？这里有很多提示和技术可以帮助您：

1.让你的照片简单

当谈到街头肖像时，简单是你的朋友。力求简单的主题、简单的背景和简单的构图。

所以在按下快门按钮之前，请仔细观察场景。有没有不必要的元素？背景是否足够简单以突出主题？整个镜头是否感觉平衡且整洁？

如果您确实注意到构图中不必要的部分，请尝试将其删除。有时，这就像向右或向左移动几步一样简单。其他时候，您可能需要靠近、远离或站到高处。

专业提示：破坏街头肖像的最快方法之一是添加繁忙、复杂的背景。杂乱的背景会让你的图像看起来很平淡，它会吞噬你的主题，并且会分散观看者的注意力。就我个人而言，我喜欢干净、色彩丰富且强烈的背景，如下所示：

中间的线条很好地平衡了主题，加上颜色和线条的强度与老人形成了很好的对比。

2. 随身携带相机和镜头

为了拍摄最佳的街头肖像，您应该随身携带相机。当然，不要像游客一样在自己的城镇里拖着整个摄影包或三脚架；即使您只是出去散步或从杂货店买东西，也只需准备好相机机身和一个镜头即可。根据我的个人经验，我可以说，走在街上，看到一些很棒的东西，却没有带相机，真是太糟糕了！

拥有一支优质而紧凑的镜头也会产生巨大的影响！我喜欢 50mm f/1.4 或 f/1.8 以及 85mm f/1.8，它们都很小而且相对较轻。

此外，这些镜头的大光圈可以通过浅景深效果很好地隔离拍摄对象。

3.了解您的相机（并选择正确的设置）

了解您的相机，尤其是其基本操作，对于捕捉街头肖像至关重要。这需要频繁且集中的练习。如果您很少使用相机，就很难流畅地使用它。

选择您觉得舒服的设置。光圈优先通常很受欢迎，因为对于街头肖像来说，控制曝光和景深非常重要。使用光圈优先模式，您可以选择光圈以获得良好的景深效果，然后您可以关注快门速度并根据需要进行整体设置调整。

现在，光圈优先可以让您快速拍照。缺点是除非使用曝光补偿，否则您只能使用相机选择的任何曝光。但这可能会减慢您的速度，因为您可能在最需要的时候没有得到补偿。

因此，掌握相机的手动模式也是一个好主意。学习手动模式可以让您更严格地控​​制曝光，并一目了然地了解您正在使用的设置。是的，需要更多练习。但除非你练习，否则你永远不会知道当你处于控制状态时你所拥有的优势。

无论您使用哪种模式，请对其充满信心。无需思考即可使用相机，让您能够更多地融入周围环境，这在拍摄肖像时尤其重要。

4.思考光和影

街头人像照明很重要！即使您在一个伟大的时刻捕捉到一个伟大的主题，如果灯光不起作用，整个镜头也会被毁掉。我有一些建议可以帮助你：

首先，避免使用相机上的内置闪光灯。这是初学者常犯的错误。对我来说，内置闪光灯仅用于为朋友或家人快速拍摄。如果您想在强光下拍摄街头肖像，请使用自然光，而不是闪光灯！

其次，尽量避免在烈日下拍摄。原因很简单：硬光意味着硬阴影！通常，当你在阳光下拍摄肖像时，它会在眼睛下方产生硬阴影，这（通常）看起来很糟糕。 （如果您已经带着相机外出并且阳光从上方照射下来，您仍然可以拍摄街头肖像 - 但您可以考虑让拍摄对象移至阴凉处。）

第三，在良好的光线下拍摄还不够。您还需要考虑光线和阴影如何落在拍摄对象的脸上。我喜欢先试拍，然后在液晶显示屏上查看，仔细注意高光和阴影。

5. 将世界分解为元素

构图是街头人像摄影的基本组成部分，但它往往是初学者的症结所在。毕竟，如何安排场景元素以获得完美的活力和平衡？

我的建议？尝试将世界分解为元素。然后告诉自己，您只是以一种有趣的方式组织世界。

看，3D眼睛和大脑使事情变得不必要地复杂，而且 - 正如我在上一篇小费中所讨论的那样 - 最好的街道肖像往往很简单。因此，您也需要简单地看到世界。

您可能会将世界分解为物体（例如，道路，窗户，门，砖块，屋顶，人等）。或者，您可能会走得更远，并以几何形状（例如，正方形，圆形，矩形等）来查看世界。要么可以工作；关键是选择一种方法并坚持下去。

然后从那里构建您的构图。寻找不同元素之间的关系。考虑他们可以在整个框架上互相平衡的方法。请记住：您只需要一个或两个有趣的元素即可拍摄照片。如果您可以识别正确的元素，并且可以以正确的方式将它们放在一起，最终将获得美丽的图像。

6.照片角色，而不是美丽

寻找美丽或英俊​​的人拍照可能很诱人。谁能怪你？但是，如果您发现有趣的人，您会创建更多有趣的街头肖像。这意味着性别和所有年龄段的人（儿童除外，请参阅下一点）。

7.使用缓慢，沉思的方法

当您第一次开始拍摄街道肖像时，这可能是一种可怕的体验。您可能会发现自己急于试图防止自己和主题之间的紧张关系。

但问题是：

最好的街头摄影需要考虑。您需要适当地看一下您的主题，尤其是他们的眼睛，这告诉您主题的感觉甚至是思维。

因此，请尽力而为。慢慢来。如果需要，请将相机用作自己和受试者之间的一种盾牌；这样，您会感到紧张局势减轻，并且可以花时间观察对象的脸部并了解他们的真正感受。

如果您刚刚开始，则可以轻松使用这种方法。首先，只需透过相机浏览即可而无需射击快门即可。然后，一旦您感到舒适，请拍摄图像。随着时间的流逝，您将获得信心，并且您将能够看到一个主题并单瞬间拍摄照片。

8.观察和预期

抓住动作时需要紧密的技巧和好运。预见潜在的动作在发生之前通常意味着您获得更稳定的照片。

我更喜欢找到一个我舒适的位置 - 也就是说，我不是以任何人的方式而不是在烈日下。我喜欢确保我也有一个很好的角度来捕获动作的发生。

知道该位置很有帮助。意识到在任何特定地方的生活流程将有助于您期望何时何地获得最好的照片。

旅行经常带您到不同和陌生的地方。在拍照之前学会停下来观察将为您带来有用的感觉。

您还可以在自己的附近捕捉街头肖像，在那里您更熟悉生活的速度和街道的感觉。但是停顿并注意仍然没有任何伤害。查看正在发生的事情，并查看模式和重复元素。

在计划和自发性之间找到平衡。做好准备。过度计划会杀死自然的感觉。您不想创建过度人为的街头照片。互联网上已经有很多！

9.寻找怪异或幽默的情况

一些最好的街道肖像向观众展示了一些意外甚至幽默的东西。这是开始捕获有意义的街头照片的最简单方法之一 - 此外，当您出门拍摄时，它会给您一些方向并使您了解周围环境。

例如，您可能会寻找做出异常手势或表达方式的人：

请注意，您的图像不需要引人注目的奇怪或大声笑。只需训练自己注意到有趣或令人困惑的行为 - 一旦发生，就将相机抬到您的眼睛上并拍照。有些镜头将起作用，而另一些则不会。没关系！通过练习，您将完善自己的风格。同时，玩得开心！

10.找到一个很好的背景并等待

认真的街头摄影师中有一种简单的技术：

您会发现一个有趣的位置，例如彩色背景，引人注目的显示器，甚至是标志。然后，您等待有人在前面行走。如果您选择一个有大量人流的区域，则合适的人会蜿蜒穿过，您将获得街头肖像 - 将令人惊叹的背景和有趣的主题结合在一起。

另外，当您不断地凝视一个区域长时间时，您会非常熟悉它。您会注意到最初没有看到的东西，然后开始理解是什么使该位置与众不同。您甚至可以决定使用不同的组合物在不同的照明下，在不同的情况下回来第二或第三或第十次。

当然，这项技术确实需要耐心，这对于街头射击者来说是一件非常好的事情（初学者通常缺乏的东西）。如果您发现自己努力在一个地方呆了几秒钟以上，请提醒自己，会出现一个好的场景；您只需要准备就绪！

11.利用颜色

一些街头肖像画家更喜欢用黑白拍摄- 但就我个人而言，我一直喜欢用彩色拍摄。颜色使您可以传达不同的感觉，并且可以使用它来移动观众，就像您可以用轻或有趣的主题移动它们一样。

因此，当您与相机一起行走时，请寻找颜色。注意五颜六色的背景，注意受试者衣服的颜色，请注意他们手中购物袋的颜色。而且，当您发现似乎可以很好地搭配在一起的颜色时，请拍照！

您还可以更加刻意的方式与色彩街头肖像进行。颜色传达不同的感觉（例如，黄色温暖而快乐，绿色是宁静的，红色的信号信心或愤怒）。如果您有一种感觉，可以找到正确的背景颜色 - 然后您可以等待（使用上一个提示中的技术！），直到完美的主题漫步为止。

12.不要害怕向陌生人问照片

近距离拍摄人可能会令人生畏。但是大多数人很高兴被拍照！这是必须记住的，当您出去和相机外出时。

如果您首先询问许可，尤其如此。只是自信和友好。礼貌地说：“您介意我拍照吗？”有时，您可以简单地示意相机，而您会得到点头或微笑。

毕竟，人类是与其他人建立联系的，而摄影是一种强大的联系形式。当您拍摄某人的照片时，您基本上是在说：“我见到你！你很重要。”对于大多数人来说，这是一个很好的赞美。

但是，在您的方法方面保持道德。不要拍摄孩子或明显脆弱的照片，如果某人不想被拍照，只需走开即可。摄影是一种交流，如果您拍摄某人，那应该是尊重的。

13.准备好设置

在接触一个人询问您是否可以拍照之前，请设置设置并准备就绪。您不想花时间摆弄相机上的表盘和按钮；否则，您的主题可能会感到恼火，您将失去机会。

换句话说，当他们说“是”时，准备举起手臂，拍了几张照片，说谢谢，然后走开。简单的。

当然，您可以随时阅读情况，如果它们对此开放，您可能会考虑粘住并捕获几枪。但是，请务必准备好以防万一！

14.总是微笑

这个技巧很快，但必不可少：

您总是想让任何与相机见到您的人都知道您是一个开朗的人。这样，他们就不会介意被您拍照！而且，如果他们介意 - 即使他们对您的问题感到生气，也只需微笑并退缩即可。

作为一名街头摄影师，您代表那里的所有其他街头射击者，所以请注意不要破坏我们的集体声誉！

15.不要要求你的主题微笑

根据我的经验，一个好的肖像比您更多。

当您要求某人微笑时，这并不自然。取而代之的是，它看起来会被迫，这对镜头来说是不好的。至少，它不会让您了解那个人是谁和他们的样子。

所以不要要求微笑！无论是微笑还是悲伤，您的主题都会揭示他们对相机的真实表达。

有时，您可能会感到惊讶！

16.注意手势

您观看人类越近，他们就越能通过手势揭示自己。在那一刻，当一个手势发生并传达了有意义的东西时，您可以捕捉有趣的肖像。

请注意，手势只是指身体的运动。因此，一个人可以用双手，眼睛，腿，手指甚至脚创造出强大的手势。

在捕获手势时，您应该仔细注意时机。毫秒可以是令人回味的手势或无聊的扁平镜头的令人惊叹的镜头之间的区别 - 因此，练习在右时练习按下快门按钮。 （您还可以考虑使用相机的连续拍摄模式，尤其是在启动时。）

我拍摄了下面的图像进行胃项目。该项目的每张照片都是完全不同的。一个人表现出自己的胃和他们做出的手势的方式，传达了很多关于自己的个性以及对自己的感觉。

17.一致练习您的方法

方法很重要。找到您的凹槽并坚持下去。如果您只尝试一次，您将永远不会掌握它。如果您经常更改方法，则需要很长时间才能建立自己的技能和风格。

找到最喜欢的相机设置和镜头，并始终如一地使用它们。选择您舒适的位置并经常重新审视它们。了解那里发生的事情以及如何拍照。当灯光和活动对您有用时去。

接近人们，询问您是否可以拍摄他们的肖像。留在阴影和照片中，恕不另行通知。即使您发现与陌生人不舒服的联系，也可以尝试这两种方式。我曾经也被石化。不过，作为报纸摄影师的工作，我不得不将自己推到舒适区域之外。那使我成为了更好的摄影师。

18.做你自己

当我主持研讨会时，我经常面对对独创性的担忧。我的学生担心世界看起来有多过分。他们担心他们不会有任何有趣的贡献，而且这已经完成了。

这是考虑街头肖像摄影的错误方式。

当然，全世界都被大量拍照，而且已经多年了。但是世界不是静态的。这是一种不断变化的生物体。没有什么可以保持不变的，因此原始照片和有趣照片的可能性实际上是无限的。

另外，虽然世界本身可能经常被拍照，但个人却没有。您有几张街头肖像？答案是“不多”，对吗？我的观点是，通过找到个人照片，您正在创建新有趣的照片。

不过，更重要的是，摄影是您是谁的表达。您可能会从捕获非原始照片开始。但是，射击那个相机越多，就越会创建图像完全表达您的表达：您的激情，经验和看到世界的方式。这足以创建您目标的独特而有趣的照片。

1.确保安全拍摄火

用科学怪人的怪物的明智话说：“火不好！”对于摄影师来说尤其如此。

如果您想做火摄影，则必须认真对待火。热量和烟雾会损坏您的设备，火焰会很快失控并燃烧，最重要的是！ - 大火可以杀死你。

可以在此网站上找到大量的大火信息，但是您应该立即记住以下一些基本安全提示：

  • 提前思考并从头到尾计划拍摄，因此您确切地知道在任何给定时间都会着火什么以及如何拍照
  • 有一个计划扑灭大火的计划
  • 不要在任何不想着火的事情附近工作
  • 在通风良好的地区工作
  • 确保您在一个地方工作，如果发生最坏的话，一切都会好起来的

3.拍摄火作为口音

4.尝试显示规模

关于火，您会注意到的第一件事是它的大小如何在照片中欺骗。有时，这种歧义为您的镜头增添了神秘感，但是在许多情况下，尤其是在大型或异常小火的情况下，传达规模至关重要。它使观众对火的存在有一种真正的感觉。例如，在没有适当规模的情况下，一张小篝火和大型篝火可能看起来非常相似。

显示比例尺的直接方法是使用更宽的镜头。这使您可以捕获火及其周围环境，将火焰放置在上下文中。大火周围的环境，无论是巨大的旷野还是舒适的后院，都讲述了一个关于大火的大小和意义的故事。

另一个有效的方法是在框架中包含参考对象。像一个坐在篝火旁的人一样简单的事情会立即为观众提供大小参考。但是请记住，安全是第一。切勿损害您的安全性或其他人的安全！

5.照相篝火

篝火以其受控而活泼的天性，是磨练您的火力摄影技巧的绝佳主题。他们提供了各种机会，从详细的火焰特写到更广泛的镜头，这些镜头在更广阔的场景中捕捉了篝火的角色。

当捕获篝火火焰的复杂细节时，更长的镜头可能是您最好的朋友。它使您可以在放大时保持安全距离以捕获火。您将能够专注于火焰中的图案和颜色，而火灾产生的抽象形式可能会导致令人着迷的图像。

但是不要只是放大火焰。如上所述，尝试将篝火作为更大场景的一部分捕获。也许这是朋友聚会或星空下宁静之夜的焦点的中心。这些更广阔的镜头创造了一种叙事，并引起了与火的温暖和光线有关的情绪。

我最喜欢的篝火摄影方面之一是捕捉被火的光芒照亮的人。温暖，闪烁的灯光呈现出独特的阴影和亮点，营造出一种奇妙的氛围。 （当然，在拍摄篝火时，请记住为弱光条件调整相机设置！）

  1. 使用长的快门速度。虽然火看起来很漂亮，但不是很明亮。为了补偿，您通常需要在1秒，5秒甚至30秒钟工作。
  2. 扩大了您的光圈。同样，这里的目标是弥补缺乏光线。如果需要，将光圈推到最大设置。
  3. 增强您的ISO。从低ISO开始通常是一个好主意 - 但是，如果您拍摄了一些测试镜头，而它们并不明亮，那么请推动您的ISO（并继续推动ISO，直到您得到所追求的结果） 。
  4. 请仔细注意灯光下降的位置。如果您在篝火旁射击，您可以在距火焰十几英尺的受试者上获得有趣的照明 - 因此不要被迫紧紧地裁剪。取而代之的是，在周围的环境中发挥创造力。

Also, when working with a wide aperture and therefore a narrow depth of field , try setting your focus on objects with high-contrast edges (like the silhouettes of stationary subjects) instead of the main subject. You'll technically miss focus, but that's okay; the shifting fire light will blur edges and soften the shadows of the objects it illuminates, so you should do what you can to nail the hard edges.

Oh, and take advantage of the interesting colors that fire offers…

…and consider emphasizing them in post-processing!

Speaking of which:

7. Learn to control the color of your flame

Take a close look at a flame, and you'll see multiple colors, gradients, and intensities depending on temperature, fuel type, oxygen quantities, how well the oxygen is mixed with the fuel, and more.

It sounds complicated, and it kind of is. But when it comes to fire photography, a few simple tips should help you control the color of your flame – and get the shots you're after.

See, when photographing fire, the most influential factor is the fuel being burned. Wood, paper, clothing, or anything else that puts off a lot of unburned particles (smoke) will probably burn yellowish-orange. Butane lighters, propane torches, liquids with high alcohol content, or other fuels that can more easily mix with the available oxygen will burn more on the bluish side.

Blue and yellow don't satisfy you?从不畏惧; there are additives (pyrotechnic colorants, to be precise) you can buy to change the color of the flame at will. I found some pre-packaged powders at my local camping store, and they worked pretty well. Or if you're into chemistry, this article describes which compounds can be used to create which colors.

And you have yet another option: Simply change the color of the fire in post-processing. Because fire colors are so dominant, it's easy to select the color and adjust it throughout the entire image. I used post-processing to achieve this interesting green flame:

8. Have fun photographing smoke

Smoke can look very cool, but unless you're taking steps to make sure it appears in your scene, you'll probably end up with smokeless shots (or totally underwhelming smoke photos, which is almost as frustrating).

Here are three things you can do to highlight smoke and capture gorgeous results:

  1. Be certain your fire is making smoke. Fuels that burn efficiently (like some gas torches and alcohols) may not emit much smoke at all. Use inefficient fuels like wood or paper to maximize your smoke output.
  2. Light the smoke. A light source shining into the smoke can solidify those lines and help them stand out. Use backlight to create the most powerful effect, while sidelight is better for a mysterious look.
  3. Use a fast shutter speed to freeze the smoke trails (start at 1/100s, but increase this if necessary). Slower shutter speeds will make the smoke appear like haze, not well-defined wisps.

Also, be sure to take plenty of images. Smoke is constantly changing shape and direction, so it's generally not enough to capture one shot and call it a day; instead, take dozens of shots, delete the mediocre ones, and keep your best.

9. Start with a candle

If you want to get started with fire photography but you're not quite ready to dive in feet first, I recommend you photograph a candle.

Candles are simple, relatively safe, and easy to work with – so you can do plenty of shooting without any high-stakes compositions.

To practice, try to accomplish the three primary types of fire shots I discussed above (fire as a subject, fire as an accent, and fire as a light source).

Then have some fun experimenting. And as you go along, make sure to write down your settings. In particular, determine the shutter speed you need to freeze the flame, as well as the shutter speed you need to illuminate a subject on a table. Finally, use an artificial light source to photograph both the flame and the surrounding environment in a single frame.

10. Look for scenes with both fire and people

Incorporating people into your fire photography can transform your images from simple shots of flames to narratively rich photos. When you capture the interplay between humans and fire, you're doing more than photographing the fire's form: you're telling a story that first began thousands of years ago. This human-focused approach offers a lot of possibilities – you can capture intimate campfire gatherings, silhouettes of a lone figure against a fireplace, or someone carefully lighting a candle.

For the most striking shots, pay careful attention to the lighting the fire provides. The warm glow on faces, the dance of shadows, and the contrast between the bright flames and the surrounding darkness all create a dramatic effect. Be attentive to these details and use them to enhance the emotional impact of your images.

Silhouettes are always worth a try. To achieve a nice result, expose for the flames, allowing your human subjects to become dark figures against the bright background. This technique can create a sense of mystery and drama, adding a layer of intrigue to your photos. But the key is balance; you want to capture the brilliance of the fire without losing the outline of the human form.

Ultimately, including people in your fire photography provides context and scale, but more importantly, it adds a human element that resonates on a deeper level.

11. Post-process your fire photos

Post-processing is crucial in fire photography. It's rare to get a perfect shot straight out of the camera, especially with something as unpredictable as flames! Fortunately, you won't need to make ultra-technical changes for the best results.

I'd encourage you to start with the basics: exposure and tonal adjustments. Adjust the main exposure slider, then play around with the shadows, highlights, and midtones to bring out details in both the fire and its surroundings.

Next, tackle the white balance. Fire can range from a warm orange to an intense blue, and getting this color right is vital for the mood of your photo. Adjust the temperature slider until the fire looks natural and appealing.

Enhancing contrast can give your fire photos some extra punch. And a slight increase in saturation can enhance the fire's vibrancy without making it look unnatural.

Don't forget about a vignette (ie, a darkening effect around the edges of the frame). Adding a subtle vignette can draw the viewer's eyes toward the main subject. But be careful not to overdo it; a heavy-handed vignette can look artificial.

Finally, for those willing to delve a bit deeper, dodging and burning can add a three-dimensional feel to your images. Lighten (dodge) areas you want to highlight, and darken (burn) parts you wish to recede. This technique can bring a lifelike quality to the flames so that they really leap off the screen.

如果您想像专业人士一样拍摄飞行中的鸟类，那么您来对地方了。

作为一名长期的鸟类摄影师，我花了无数的时间通过取景器跟踪鸟类，应对拍摄完美鸟类照片所带来的挫败感、困难和兴奋。

我犯过很多错误，但我也发现了很多很多可以立即提升你的照片质量的技巧和技巧。

在这篇文章中，我的目标是分享这一切。我将解释所有鸟类飞行摄影基础知识，包括装备选择、位置选择、灯光、 构图等等。

Let's dive right in.

1. 选择鸟类飞翔的最佳位置

美丽的飞鸟摄影从您的位置开始。

某些地区根本没有鸟类；其他人可能有鸟，但它们会在错误的地方，或者在提供有限照片访问的地方。根据我的经验，最好设置在河流或湖泊附近，因为它们为鸟类提供了丰富的食物来源，而且您通常可以沿着水边移动不同的角度。

您也可以尝试在线快速搜索您附近的最佳观鸟地点。或者，您可以找到列出鸟类计数数据的观鸟论坛或观鸟博客；这样，您就可以根据目标鸟类种类前往您感兴趣的地点。

找到位置后，观察飞翔的鸟类片刻。寻找一个位置——在河岸或山上——让你尽可能接近鸟的高度。 （换句话说，你不想从下面向上射击或从上面向下射击。你想要尽可能直接、正前方的角度。）

并检查太阳的位置，因为你不应该向它拍摄。首选来自您身后或您所在位置左侧或右侧的光线。

此外，鸟类通常会在风中起飞和降落，因此了解风向将有助于您预测所拍摄鸟类的飞行路径。

在飞行地点找到最好的鸟需要大量的试验和错误。你去的许多地点都是无用的——但这是值得的，因为偶尔你会发现一个可以一次又一次返回的区域。侦察足够多的地点，您最终会得到这些热点的详细列表！

2.在最佳光线下拍摄

如果您想要拍摄飞行中的大鸟照片，您需要在光线最好的时候出发，至少在您刚出发时是这样。

（随着时间的推移，您将学习在不良光线下工作的技巧 - 但作为初学者，在昏暗的光线下拍摄会拍出惨淡的照片。）

那么在飞行摄影中什么才是鸟类的最佳光线呢？

早晨和傍晚的金色光芒，通常被称为黄金时段，由于其绚丽、柔和的效果，是完美的。确实，只要你在日出后的两个小时和日落前的两个小时内拍摄，光线就会看起来很棒（不过请记住，你需要仔细选择你的位置；你希望从正面照亮鸟儿，而不是从侧面照亮）。后退！）。

另外，因为您拍摄的是空中的鸟类，所以即使您在黄金时间之前或之后拍摄，您仍然会在拍摄对象上获得良好的照明（只需确保光线不会变得太刺眼！）。

3.让自己隐形

大多数鸟类都有不同程度的易受惊吓，因此，如果您的目标是捕捉充满画面的图像，则需要尽可能让自己隐形。

首先避免穿颜色鲜艳的衣服。当您接近鸟类热点时，您也可以保持离地面较低的位置，或使用自然掩护物（例如树木）。当你变得更认真时，你可能会考虑穿迷彩服，使用百叶窗，甚至从车窗拍摄（鸟类往往不太受汽车打扰，所以你经常可以开车靠近通常会飞走的鸟类）。

一旦找到一个好地方，就保持相对静止。不要做任何突然的动作。相反，在设置相机时保持一切缓慢而稳定，然后如果可以的话坐下（我建议保持低调）。

4.使用正确的装备

您几乎可以使用任何现代数码单反相机或无反光镜相机拍摄飞行中的鸟类，但最好的型号提供：

  • 取景器（这样您就可以轻松追踪飞过天空的鸟儿）
  • 快速连拍速度（因此您可以捕捉一系列瞬间图像，至少其中一张看起来不错）
  • 良好的高 ISO 性能（因此您可以在低光照条件下提高相机的ISO ，而不必担心噪点）
  • 良好的自动对焦性能（因此您可以跟踪在空中编织和俯冲的拍摄对象）

通常，您在开始时需要做出妥协，但请尝试尽可能多地检查上述框。

您还需要获得最好的镜头，它通常具有以下四个功能：

  • 长焦距（至少300mm，500mm或600mm更好）
  • 宽大的最大光圈（f/4 是理想选择，但 f/5.6-f/6.3 也可以使用，特别是如果您不打算在弱光下拍摄）
  • 锐利的光学器件
  • 快速自动对焦

同样，这里可能需要做出妥协；最好的鸟类飞行摄影镜头要花费数千美元，这对于初学者来说毫无意义。因此，购买您能买得起的最好的镜头，然后学会如何很好地使用它！

我还建议您使用坚固的三脚架和良好的万向节云台。它将帮助您在跟踪鸟类时平衡您的设置（尽管较便宜的选择是平头，它也可以很好地工作）。最后，虽然球头可以用于飞行摄影中的鸟类，但对于大镜头来说它们并不是一个非常稳定的解决方案，所以我一般不推荐它们。

5.学习你的科目

如果您想成为一名出色的鸟类摄影师，那么您需要研究鸟类。

为什么？一旦你了解了鸟类，你就可以预测它们的动作。例如，许多鸟类，尤其是苍鹭或鹰等较大的物种，会在飞行前大小便。了解这一点可以给你一个瞬间的警告，转化为一个漂亮的起飞镜头。

事实上，很多这样的学习都会在你外出摄影时进行。只需观察鸟类，通过识别它们的行为习惯，通过观察它们做什么以及何时做，您就会积累大量有用的知识。

例如，您是否知道滨鸟倾向于以一致的方向沿着海滩奔跑？因此，如果您想拍摄飞行中惊慌失措的滨鸟的特写镜头，请确定它们的方向，在海滩上找到自己的位置，趴在地上，等待它们来找您！

（这就是你在海滩上花了几个小时观察鸟类后学到的东西！）

6. 拍摄一些起飞和着陆镜头

飞行中的鸟类摄影并不总是关于鸟类在天空中翱翔的画面。您也可以通过为美丽的起飞和着陆时刻做好准备来拍摄一些令人惊叹的照片。

这里的关键是了解鸟类的行为方式。例如，大多数鸟类在起飞前经常排便以减轻负载。这是获得精彩起飞镜头的非常重要的线索。当然，这还取决于您的位置和光线方向，以充分利用这种情况。

风向对于获得更好的起飞和着陆镜头起着重要作用，因为在这些场景中鸟类经常逆风飞行。因此，明智的做法是让自己的视线远离风的主要方向。这样，鸟儿就会面向您降落和起飞。

7. 正确设置鸟类的飞行相机

要在飞行摄影中确定鸟类的正确相机设置，您需要平衡您的艺术需求（例如景深和清晰度）与曝光需求。它可能会变得有点复杂，特别是因为为飞行中的鸟类选择设置不同于为更一般的拍摄鸟类选择设置。

不过，我确实有一些建议可以极大地简化流程。

首先，使用光圈优先模式；这样，您就可以随时控制光圈和 ISO（通过提高 ISO 或扩大光圈，您可以提高快门速度）。

其次，将光圈设置为 f/8 左右。这是你的镜头最清晰的地方，而且它会给你足够的景深来获得翼尖到翼尖的清晰度。

第三，将ISO设置为最低值，通常在ISO 100左右。这里的目标是避免提高ISO，这会产生噪音。也就是说，在弱光条件下拍摄时，您需要提高 ISO 来提高快门速度。

现在，对于飞行中的鸟类摄影来说，快门速度可能是最重要的设置，因为如果速度太慢，鸟的翅膀就会模糊，这样看起来很少会很好。一般来说，我建议使用至少 1/1000 秒的快门速度，1/2000 秒及以上更好。 （不过，你的最低快门速度会根据鸟的速度而改变；飞行中的大型鸟类，如苍鹭和鹅，速度很慢，而飞行中的小型鸟类，如鹪鹩，则在天空中飞翔。）

无论如何，拨入光圈和 ISO，然后查看快门速度，相机将纯粹根据曝光考虑来选择快门速度。问问自己：这个快门速度足够快吗？如果是这样，那么你就很出色了，但如果不是，你需要提高 ISO 或扩大光圈，以便你的相机有足够的光线来提高快门速度。

我建议在调整光圈之前提高 ISO。但是，如果您的 ISO 逐渐进入嘈杂区域，那么扩大光圈可能是有意义的，而不是冒着图像噪音过大的风险。

拨入所有设置后，我建议您进行快速测试。拍摄一些附近鸟类的照片（它们不需要很好地构图 - 目标是确保快门速度足够快并且光圈足够窄）。放大相机液晶显示屏，确保一切看起来都很好，然后享受拍摄飞行中的鸟类的乐趣！

8.学习良好的对焦技巧

鸟类速度很快，这意味着您需要付出一些认真的努力才能获得始终如一的锐利镜头。

首先，您需要将相机设置为连续对焦模式。这样，每当您半按快门按钮时，焦点就会接合，然后随着拍摄对象的移动而重新对焦。 （尼康和许多其他制造商将这种模式称为“AF-C”，而佳能将其称为“AI Servo”。）

您应该将相机设置为最快连拍模式，也称为连拍模式。当鸟儿飞过时，您可以快速连续地捕捉一系列图像。

接下来，您需要启用相机的跟踪 AF 区域模式。它会告诉你的相机在画面中跟踪这只鸟，即使它左右、上下飞行等。具体细节将取决于你的相机，但某种形式的“跟踪”应该可以解决问题。另外，如果您的相机提供此功能，请尝试激活动物眼自动对焦，它将通过画面专门识别和跟踪鸟类的眼睛。

然后，一旦设置好相机，当鸟儿 a) 栖息并即将起飞，或 b) 飞向远处时，就开始对焦它。半按快门按钮，并在鸟起飞和/或靠近时继续跟踪它。一旦鸟儿飞入主要区域，完全按下快门按钮，连拍几张照片，然后——祈祷吧！ – 你会得到一个好的结果。

一些额外的提示：

当鸟儿飞过时，即使停止射击，也要继续平移。与突然停止相比，这种连续运动将使您的最后一张图像更好地保持焦点。

此外，当鸟儿飞过时平移时，您需要将平移速度与鸟儿的速度相匹配。即使您被迫降低快门速度，完美的摇摄也能让鸟儿保持清晰，而背景则变得模糊。

目标是保持鸟眼的焦点和锐利；这是关键。如果您手持设置，请尝试将左手放在镜头镜筒下方，并将肘部靠近身体，因为这将帮助您尽可能稳定地操纵相机。如果您站立，请将双腿分开，以形成坚固的基础。

最后，如果您打算暂时固定您的位置和位置，我建议您使用三脚架。这将有助于保持相机稳定，特别是当您使用非常重的镜头时。

9.等待对比背景

在之前关于飞行摄影中鸟类的技巧中，我讨论了正确对焦的重要性。但我想分享另一件对我自己的摄影来说非常宝贵的物品：

寻找对比鲜明的背景。

假设您正在跟踪小鸟以锁定焦点，但您的镜头正在寻找焦点。请记住，对焦系统需要拍摄对象和背景之间有足够好的对比度才能确定拍摄对象 - 当鸟儿在蓝天等干净的背景上飞行时，自动对焦系统通常很容易锁定焦点。

因此，不要左右射击，而是等到鸟飞过对比鲜明的背景，或者重新定位自己，以便下次鸟飞过时，背景会更加对比鲜明。

10.从慢飞的鸟开始

如果您在没有真正了解正确技术的情况下选择拍摄飞行中的鸟类，通常会导致令人沮丧的结果。

正确的握持和对焦技巧并不难学，但确实需要时间。在掌握这些技术方面，练习是无可替代的。因此，学习它们的最好方法是投入时间，但你会想做得正确。

换句话说，不要从鸣禽在天空中飞过时开始；而是从它们开始。相反，从白鹭和苍鹭等缓慢飞行的鸟类开始，然后逐步向上！

11.以强有力的构图为目标

对于鸟类摄影师来说，构图可能很困难，但不用担心；您可以使用一些基本规则来在飞行镜头中捕捉一致构图良好的鸟类。

首先，您始终可以使用三分法则，它告诉您将鸟（或鸟眼）定位在画面的三分之一处，而不是死点。

我还建议使用空间规则，它要求您在鸟的前面放置比其后面更多的空间（一个好的指导原则是在鸟的前面至少留出两到三倍的空间，这将有助于无论如何，你遵循三分法则！）。

此外，虽然大多数飞行中的鸟类照片只包含一只鸟，但请寻找可以同时捕捉两只或三只鸟的场合，以获得独特的效果。

12.调整你的观点

通常，鸟类飞行照片好坏的区别在于视角。这只鸟是从下面捕获的吗？脑袋上？与眼睛齐平吗？每次改变视角，效果都会不同。

例如，拍摄一只在头顶上方飞行的鸟与拍摄一只飞过的鸟会产生不同的效果。一张飞向你的鸟的照片比一张飞离你的鸟的照片产生的影响更大。用眼睛水平拍摄一只飞翔的鸟会产生亲密的效果。

因此，在拍摄时，不要满足于单一视角。改变一下吧！

飞行中的鸟类摄影：最后的话


飞行中的鸟类摄影并不容易，需要大量练习才能获得完美的照片。

但一旦你做对了，你就会上瘾！

因此，请记住这些提示，带上相机出去玩吧！

如果您购物预算有限，那么购买二手相机装备是个好主意。

现代数码相机会定期更新，因此二手市场上充满了寻找新家的相机。二手相机是在不花太多钱的情况下升级装备的好方法（而且它们通常也物超所值）。

但在二手市场购物会遇到很多陷阱，如果没有仔细的策​​略，您可能会发现自己在有缺陷或损坏的设备上浪费时间、精力和金钱。

作为一名经常依赖二手市场的摄影师，我知道如何避免这些问题，下面，我分享了一个分步方法，以便您可以成功购买自己的二手装备，以及一些指导，以确保你会得到最好的回报。这样，您就可以以原价的一小部分更新您的相机、镜头和配件！

如何购买二手相机装备：基本的 4 步流程

当您第一次购买二手或翻新设备时，这种简单的方法应该会有所帮助：

第 1 步：购买前检查二手商品的价格

几乎每个在线相机零售商在其网站上都有二手专区。物品的可用性是可变的，但简单的物品检查可以估算出您想要的物品的当前标准使用价格。

在您点击购买按钮之前，我鼓励您查看多个网站，确定平均价格和最低价格，以确定最适合您需求的购买方式。

也就是说，不要简单地被最低价格所吸引！请务必记下每个项目的质量评级和描述，并查看其与您的期望相比如何。通常，价格过低的二手商品都会存在某种外观或机械问题，因此，如果您认为这笔交易好得令人难以置信，那么它可能就是真的。

怀疑价格过低的另一个原因是什么？该商品可能是灰色市场商品，这意味着它基本上没有工厂保修。检查这一点的最佳方法是找到序列号并在相机制造商的数据库中引用它。

与亲自购买二手装备相比，在线购买二手装备的优势在于，零售商经常检查装备并对其进行评级。此外，在线二手装备，尤其是直接来自用户的二手装备，往往比从专门的实体零售商购买的二手装备便宜得多。如果您对购买不满意，换货和退货方面也可能有一定的灵活性。

专业提示：在购买之前，请务必仔细检查并确保卖家拥有良好的声誉，尤其是在亚马逊和 eBay 等市场上。

第 2 步：询问任何相关问题

如果您走进相机店并亲自检查您想要购买的装备（请参阅下一步），则可能没有必要。但如果您在网上购买，您通常会使用有限的商品描述，如果您不小心，您最终可能会购买到不符合您期望的相机或镜头。

这就是为什么仔细阅读装备描述并提出具体问题以收集任何缺失的信息非常重要。有些卖家根本不知道某些相关的花絮，需要一些提示才能获得所需的信息。别人会刻意隐瞒相关信息，购买前一定要查明真相。

你可能会想：如果卖家不透露相关信息，我就直接退货吧？

不幸的是，事情没那么简单。根据退货政策，您可能只能退回与描述不符的商品。如果描述非常模糊，您可能很难获得免费退货 - 而如果您提出具体问题，您的情况就会容易得多！

因此，请确保您提交了大量相关问题。购买二手相机时，请询问：

  • 相机有多少个快门按钮？
  • 传感器是否有明显的污垢或灰尘点？

购买二手镜头时，请询问：

  • 镜片是否有真菌或雾霾？
  • 镜头的前部或后部元件是否有划痕？
  • 镜头是否有大块灰尘？
  • 镜头自动对焦效果好吗？
  • 镜头自动对焦机构是否有沙子？

其中一些问题可能看起来很奇怪，但您会对相机或镜头中出现的情况感到惊讶。安全总比后悔好！

第三步：检查齿轮

如果您打算亲自购买装备，通常可以在同意购买设备之前进行检查。但如果您在线购买装备，则需要在收到时进行彻底检查。毕竟，您不想使用镜头一个月后才发现某个功能不起作用！

此检查应根据您购买的商品而有所不同。

如何检查二手相机

用过的相机机身可能很难评估，但正确的方法将为您省去很多麻烦。虽然机身出现磨损迹象是完全正常的，但请注意您对相机的第一印象。如果相机看起来磨损严重且使用频繁，那么它的内部看起来可能也好不到哪儿去。

然而，影响相机机身寿命的最重要部分是快门，更换它的成本非常昂贵。人们有时会在快门即将失效时出售相机，这意味着新主人很快就不得不花费大量额外的钱来更换它。这就是为什么在收到相机后立即评估快门次数很重要；如何检查这一点以及可接受的启动次数取决于相机的品牌和型号。谷歌搜索和论坛应该提供一些资源。

确保您还测试了相机的自动对焦功能。确保单次和连续自动对焦均按预期执行，并检查安装座以确保镜头与相机牢固连接。

我还建议进行一些测试并在 100% 放大倍数下检查结果。寻找明显的灰尘点和任何模糊区域，这可能表明潜在的虐待（并可能极大地影响您的图像）。

如何检查用过的镜头

镜片的评估相对简单。首先，彻底检查镜头并查找常见问题，例如真菌、灰尘和划痕。用光照射镜头并识别任何缺陷。请注意，一些问题（例如灰尘和小划痕）实际上只是装饰性的，通常不会影响整体图像质量。然而，任何真菌迹象都应该彻底破坏交易，因为清除它非常困难且成本高昂。您还应该检查镜头隐形眼镜，确保它们看起来相对干净且状况良好。

其次，对镜头进行机械测试，看看其性能如何。最好随身携带普通相机，看看镜头是否合适。确保光圈叶片干净并且可以自由移动，然后尝试变焦环和对焦环。根据镜头型号的不同，环提供一定阻力的情况并不罕见，但请确保它们都能相对平稳地运行。检查镜头的自动对焦功能并确保对焦顺畅。

最后，拍摄一些测试照片（您可以在线找到测试图）并放大至 100% 以评估图像质量。寻找异常量的色差、前焦或后焦问题、异常柔和度以及整个画面清晰度的显着变化。确保在一系列焦距和焦点处拍摄测试照片。 （请注意，许多镜头从中心到角落以及从变焦范围的中间到极端的清晰度确实有所不同。但是从画面的一侧到另一侧，或从画面的一端，清晰度会急剧下降变焦范围到另一个，这不是一个好兆头。）

第 4 步：保留装备（或将其寄回）

如果您按照前面的步骤操作并且对购买感到满意，请继续保留它！您可能已经以非常便宜的价格买到了一台很棒的相机、镜头或配件。

但是，如果您在检查过程中发现一些问题，则由您决定设备是否值得退回。如果问题虽小但很严重，您通常可以向卖家要求折扣。如果问题很严重，我建议只退回装备；尝试自己解决问题或将设备送去维修通常不值得花费成本或麻烦。

如何购买二手相机：深入指南

相机是复杂的机器，因此在购买二手机身时需要注意一些关键指标。虽然我在上面讨论了其中一些元素，但值得更深入地探索它们：

快门数

相机的快门次数就是快门在其使用寿命内被触发的次数。

（快门计数也称为快门启动次数。）

一般来说，快门计数可以很好地表明相机的使用量，类似于检查汽车的行驶里程。相机根据快门耐用性进行评级，发烧友型号的额定拍摄次数通常约为 150,000 张，专业型号的额定拍摄次数为 300,000 张或更高。

浏览时，快门次数低通常表示使用次数较少的项目。 2-5年相机的拍摄次数少于10,000张是非常低的，正常数量在30,000-50,000张左右。

如果相机的计数非常高，达到 100,000 或更多，那么最好避免使用它，特别是因为这个数字还可以让您稍微了解所有者对相机的使用情况。较高计数的相机可能用于专业用途（以及更艰苦的生活），而较低计数则表明休闲消费者使用。

那么如何知道相机的快门次数呢？

二手相机出售时通常会提供该编号。但如果您不确定，可以根据型号通过多种方式找到答案。查看这篇文章以获取指导： 查找相机当前的快门动作。

相机检查

在查看二手相机时，您可以检查一些事项以更好地了解其状况。

首先，取下机身盖，检查反光镜、对焦屏和镜头触点周围的相机内部。寻找这些区域是否有任何损坏、油污或粘稠物的迹象。

油污可能表明内部部件的机械装置无法正常工作，有时是由于相机受到碰撞或跌落所致。检查内部侧面周围是否有油迹。一个小手电筒在这里可以发挥很大的作用。

请记住尽可能正面朝下握住相机，以减少灰尘和污垢污染的风险。

如果您手头有镜头，则值得进行一次测试以查找传感器是否存在任何问题。

将相机设置为 f/16 至 f/22，将其对准明亮的拍摄对象（白墙或天空），然后拍摄一张照片。回放图像并放大 LCD 屏幕以查找任何痕迹和划痕。

灰尘点并不是一个大问题，因为简单的传感器清洁就可以解决它们。但线条可能是传感器上划痕的证据（这意味着最好避免使用相机）。

一般磨损

当然，寻找任何外部损坏迹象也很重要。轻微的划痕、磨损和痕迹是正常的，但严重的瑕疵则可能表明相机曾跌落过。橡胶握把经常会因频繁使用而开始脱落，但可以以较低的成本进行更换。

How to buy used lenses: an in-depth guide

Camera lenses are expensive, so secondhand options are a great alternative to buying new.

Once again, however, there are a few things to look for when making a purchase.

Lens blemishes

When inspecting a lens, you'll want to check both the external and internal optics.

Externally, look for any scratches or chips on the glass. Tilting the lens toward the light can help you make sure the optics are in great condition.

Note that, even if a lens has a front filter, it may not be optically perfect. So unscrew the filter and check the true front element to be sure.

Often, lenses will show signs of wear on their focus or zoom ring and the external barrel. Simple rubbing is normal and isn't usually a concern.

Moving on, inspect internally for dust and mold. Shine a small light inside the lens and look for any particles. Most lenses will have small dust spots, but look for any large patches or seemingly smeared areas, as these will indicate whether the lens has any fogging or other internal issues.

Aperture blades

On the rear of the lens, you'll find a small lever that you can push to open the aperture blades . Do this, and check if the blades are snappy and without any stickiness that could be a sign of collected oil.

Look through the lens with the iris fully open, once again checking for any particles or oil spots.

清晰度

Check the lens sharpness using a test chart. These patterned charts are easy to find online, and they can be stuck on a wall and used to quickly evaluate a lens.

它的工作原理如下：

Mount the lens on a camera, then put the camera on a tripod. Focus on the test chart, then fire the camera using a remote release or the self-timer (to make sure you don't create any camera shake).

Check the shots on your camera LCD (or, if you can, on the computer). Zoom into 100% to be sure of focus. Of course, some cameras and lenses will need fine in-camera adjustments for perfection, but any wildly unsharp tests may indicate a lens has been dropped or is out of alignment.

It's also a good idea to test the full aperture range and look for sharpness from edge to edge. Even at f/2.8, the center of your test image should be relatively sharp.

Additionally, it's a good idea to look for any external marks or blemishes when performing these tests, turning the focus and zoom rings to check for any stickiness or grating sounds.

With those checks done, you'll have a good indication of whether the lens is up to scratch (and worth purchasing!).

Where to purchase used camera gear

If you're struggling to find high-quality used camera gear, here are a few suggestions:

Camera shops

Lots of camera retailers offer some secondhand stock as well as new cameras. Buying from a dealer has its advantages, because items are often checked before being added to the inventory, plus they're often serviced before they're sold.

Also, most dealers will have a return policy, so if you find any faults, you can exchange the used gear for a full refund. Many of the better dealers offer warranties on used gear that range from three months to a year, which will give you excellent peace of mind when purchasing.

Of course, one of the downsides of buying from a dealer is the increased price. Used kit bought from outlets often costs more than gear bought from private sellers – so you must decide if it's worth that added peace of mind!

Ebay and private sellers

Purchasing from private sellers directly offers the best chance to find a bargain. Some people sell their gear at far below the market value. If you know what to look for, and are confident about the quality and genuine nature of the sale, you can often get an excellent deal.

It pays to be wary when shopping for used camera gear, though. Be suspicious of any deal that looks too good to be true, or of buyers who will only accept cash in person. Using PayPal or PayPal alternatives offers an additional layer of protection (one that's very important in online sales).

Of course, private sellers generally won't offer a warranty, but that is a risk you take to get a bargain.

5 questions to ask before buying used camera gear

I've bought a lot of used gear over the last decade. A lot of those purchases turned out great. Some of them I still use to this day.

But a large chunk of the used purchases I made?

垃圾。

In fact, in my more naive years, I was forced to return over 50% of the gear that I purchased. There were just so many problems: sand in focusing rings, stains on the front element, shutter buttons that couldn't communicate with the shutter. (Oh, and my least favorite: Fungus inside the lens. Doesn't that just make you shiver?)

And here's the kicker:

I bought all of this gear through respectable buyers, who described the equipment as in “excellent condition,” “flawless,” “perfect,” “like new,” – you name it.

It got so bad that I considered leaving the used market entirely and just buying new. But I resisted.

为什么？

Used camera gear is a real bargain – if you buy carefully. This is why I took all of my negative gear-buying experiences and turned them into a process for making sure I purchased good used gear.

At the core of that process is a series of questions. Questions that I'm going to share with you today. Some of the questions are for you, the buyer. Others should be posed to the seller before you put any cash down.

Are you ready to discover how to buy used gear effectively?

让我们开始吧！

Question 1: Are you buying from a reputable seller with a money-back guarantee?

This is the number one most important thing that you should do when buying used gear.

Purchase from a seller that you trust – and that gives you an enforceable money-back guarantee. You don't want to purchase a camera online, only to find that it's full of water damage and sports a cracked LCD.

This means that buying used through Amazon is fine. All of their products are backed by Amazon month-long guarantees.

Buying used through eBay is also fine. Ebay's buyer protection ensures that you're not going to get ripped off in such an obvious fashion.

But this makes most forums (if not all forums) off-limits. If the forum doesn't have a serious money-back guarantee that's honored by the site itself, then stay away.

This also makes in-person sales off-limits, such as those done through Craigslist. Sure, you can inspect the item upon receipt, but what are you going to do when you get home, put that lens under a light, and realize it's filled with an army of fungus?

It'll be too late, and your seller may not be so receptive to a return.

So just don't do it. Instead, use sites like Amazon, eBay, B&H , or KEH , which all have clear money-back guarantees.

Question 2: Does the seller include actual pictures of the gear?

Sellers not including pictures is a big warning sign, especially on a website like eBay, where pictures are the norm. It should make you ask: Why doesn't the seller want to show off their “excellent condition” item? Is there something they're trying to hide?

Another red flag is only showing a stock photo. These are easy to spot; they look way better than anything that a casual, eBay-selling photographer would have taken, and there tends to be only one or two of them.

If you like the price and everything else checks out, then go ahead and shoot the seller an email, asking for in-depth pictures of the item. If the seller refuses, then it's time to look elsewhere.

You might come across some sellers who are offering many units of the same item (eg, five Canon 7D Mark II's ). In this case, they likely have shown a stock photo, or a photo of one item, because they don't want to go through the effort of photographing each piece of kit.

In such cases, you should message the seller and ask for pictures of the exact item that you'll be purchasing. It's too easy, especially with these big sellers, to end up with an item that you'll have to send back.

Question 3: How many shutter actuations has the camera fired?

(Note: This section is for buying cameras.)

First things first: A shutter actuation refers to a single shot taken with a camera.

Every camera has a number of actuations its shutter is rated for. Once the shutter has reached around that point, it just…fails. While you can get the shutter replaced, it generally costs enough that you're probably better off buying a new camera body.

If you want to know the shutter actuation rating of any particular camera, you can look it up through a quick Google search.

Of course, the shutter rating isn't a hard and fast rule. There are some cameras that go far beyond their predicted shutter count, and there are some cameras that fail far sooner. The shutter count is just an average.

Now, when you look at camera listings online, you'll see that shutter actuations are reported about fifty percent of the time.

But the other fifty percent of the time, there will be no mention of them.

This is for three possible reasons:

  1. The seller doesn't know about the importance of shutter actuations.
  2. The seller can't figure out how to determine the shutter actuations for their camera.
  3. The seller doesn't wish to share the shutter count because it won't help the sale.

I would never buy a camera without knowing its shutter count. Therefore, I recommend reaching out to the seller and asking.

If the seller refuses to share the count, then let the camera go. If the seller claims they don't know how to view the shutter count, explain that they should be able to find it easily, either within the camera itself or through a website such as https://www.camerashuttercount.com/ .

If they still won't give you the count, then don't buy. It's not worth risking it.

Question Four: Does the lens have any blemishes on the glass, fungus, scratches, haze, or problems with the focusing ring?

(Note that this is for purchasing lenses.)

This is a question to ask the seller, and I suggest you do it every single time you make a purchase.

Yes, the seller may be annoyed by your specific question. But this is a transaction; it's not about being nice to the seller! And I've never had someone refuse to sell to me because I annoyed them with questions.

In fact, what makes this question so valuable is that it often forces sellers to actually consider the equipment they're selling. Up until this point, the seller may not have really thought about some of these things. So it can act as a bit of a wake-up call and make the seller describe the item beyond “excellent condition.”

When you ask this question, make it clear that you want a detailed description. You genuinely want the seller to check for scratches on the glass, fungus in the lens , problems with the focusing ring, and more. You don't want a perfunctory examination.

Unfortunately, there will still be some people who don't do a serious examination, or who lie in the hopes that you won't notice the issues (or be bothered enough to make a return). But asking the question is the best you can do.

Question Five: Has the seller noticed any issues with the item in the past?

This is another question to ask the seller before you hit the Buy button. It's meant as a final attempt to determine whether the item has any issues.

In this case, by asking about the item's past.

Unfortunately, there will be sellers who have had an item break repeatedly – but, as long as it's working at the moment they take the photos, they'll give it the “perfect condition” label. Fortunately, many sellers will still be honest with you. If they've had a problem with the item, they'll say.

So it's definitely worth asking – just to be safe.

Buying used camera gear: final words

Buying used camera gear is all about taking your time to search out a bargain. Carefully study the used gear you're considering, whether it's from a dealer or a private seller, and look out for the telltale signs of damage.

Assuming you use careful consideration and do a thorough inspection before buying, the used market is a fantastic way to trade up your gear at a fraction of the cost of buying new.

And this, in turn, gives you money to buy additional equipment – or even better, a trip or two on which you can use it!

有时，我感觉自己被诅咒了。 Like any parent, I want to take pictures of my kids doing their activities – but my daughter is a gymnast, which means I'm stuck dealing with a toxic combination of very fast action and generally poor light.

If you've ever tried to capture low-light sports games or dance recitals, you'll understand my frustration. Action plus bad light generally leads to one of three things:

  • 照片模糊
  • Noisy/grainy photos
  • A deer-in-the-headlights flash look

And when I first started photographing my daughter, I was constantly plagued by these problems. Fortunately, however, I didn't give up, and I developed a handful of tips and techniques that allow you to capture stunning action shots when the light is terrible. That's what I share in the article below.

So if you're ready to learn how to photograph basketball, swimming, ballet, gymnastics, or any other fast-paced indoor activity, then prepare yourself for 16 hands-on tips, starting with:

1. Understand the event

Capturing the essence of an indoor sports event or a dance recital in low light isn't just about having the right equipment or knowing the right settings. And while I talk about those in detail below, I want to start with something even more critical:

Understanding what you're photographing. The more you know about the event, the better your shots will be.

Start with the basics: learn the rules of the game. If it's basketball, know when the key plays happen. If it's a dance performance, understand the sequence of movements. This knowledge lets you anticipate the action. You'll know where to position yourself and when to press the shutter.

但不要就此止步。 If you're photographing a team or group for a full season, get to know the players or the performers. Each athlete, each dancer has their unique style. Learning about them can help you predict their movements, allowing you to capture more compelling and personal images.

One of the best ways to get a feel for the event is to attend rehearsals or prior games. Observe how the action unfolds. Note the lighting conditions. Plan out potential shots – and then, when the big game occurs, you'll be able to envision amazing images just before the action heats up.

2. Use Manual mode

Before you even think about pressing that shutter button, make sure your camera is set up for success – starting with your shooting mode.

No matter the mode you normally use, in low-light scenarios, you need a lot of control over your camera's settings. That's where Manual mode comes in; it gives you complete control, so it's generally a good choice. But if you're not comfortable using Manual or you're dealing with changing light conditions, use Aperture Priority instead.

3. Use fast lenses

Next, you'll need to decide which lens to use. It's a simple process, fortunately: Choose your longest and fastest (ie, wide-apertured) lens . The low-light environment means that you'll need a fast lens to let in plenty of light. And since action subjects tend to be far away, you'll also need a longer focal length. I personally use a 70-200mm f/2.8 lens and it works great, though you could also go longer (or wider) depending on the scenario.

If your lens is on the shorter side, you may be inclined to use a teleconverter to get some extra reach. (If you aren't familiar with teleconverters, they are extensions that fit between your camera and lens; they're designed to increase the magnification of the lens). In certain contexts, teleconverters work great, but in a low-light environment, they don't; you see, teleconverters actually sacrifice light, which will magnify the problems caused by dark interiors.

So if you need extra reach, purchase a longer lens or shoot wider and crop the image in post-processing.

4. Shoot wide open

Once you've chosen your shooting mode and your lens, it's time to prepare the shot. The first exposure setting is the aperture , and when it comes to photographing in low light, picking an aperture is easy:

Set it to its widest available option (ie, the smallest f-number, which is generally f/4, f/2.8, or even wider).

This will let in the most light (which in turn will allow you to keep your shutter speed fast and your ISO low). The downside, however, is that you'll get a very shallow depth of field , so the area of sharpness within your images will be very narrow.

In this context, however, that shouldn't matter. You'll only need to keep your subject in focus, and having some background blur should be fine (or even preferable).

5. Set a fast shutter speed

Next, you'll need to set your shutter speed , and the trick here is to make sure it's fast . If your subject is not moving, then you can use the Reciprocal Rule (which states that you should choose a shutter speed that's the inverse of your lens's focal length).

However, if your subject is moving, you'll need to crank your shutter speed upward. I find that 1/200s is the minimum you need for a moving subject if you want to avoid blur. I'd recommend starting there, then increasing it if you can.

And try hard to avoid using a slower shutter speed unless you are deliberately hoping to convey a sense of movement. Otherwise, even if your images look tack-sharp on the camera LCD, you may be very disappointed when you get back to your computer to find you have a card full of blurry files.

6. Set the ISO as high as necessary (but no higher!)

So you've chosen your aperture and shutter speed; now you need to dial in an ISO .

While picking an ISO may seem complex, it's actually pretty easy. Just set the ISO to the value you need to achieve a proper exposure !

Don't be alarmed if you need to give the ISO a significant boost. I routinely use ISO 1600 or 3200, and sometimes I even set it to ISO 6400. In most other scenarios, I wouldn't even think about using such a high ISO value, but they're often necessary when photographing low-light action.

7. Test the exposure before the action begins

Once the action starts, you'll often need to start shooting with abandon, and you won't have any time to test out your exposure and make modifications.

That's why I encourage you to arrive early for any scheduled events, find your seat (or a good vantage point), and spend some time taking exposure test shots.

Since you'll generally be indoors, the light probably won't change over the course of the event, so you can generally just set your exposure settings and forget about them while you concentrate on the action. (Of course, if the light is changing, you'll need to frequently take breaks to test your exposure.)

8. Do plenty of experimentation

When you're trying to capture fast-paced action in low light, it's easy to make mistakes, to mess up, to end up with images that are blurry or poorly composed or slightly behind the moment. The key to dealing with this?实验。

Your first few shots might be a bit off. Maybe you chose a shutter speed that's too slow, causing blur. Or perhaps your AF mode wasn't quite right, leading to focus issues.这是完全正常的。 The trick is to keep trying different settings. Play around with your shutter speed. Adjust your ISO. Change your focus mode.

And don't be afraid to take loads of photos. Review them on the spot. See what works and what doesn't. This hands-on learning is invaluable. You'll start to understand what settings work best in the specific lighting you're dealing with. And before you know it, you'll be capturing those dynamic, sharp action shots with ease.

9. Zoom in

This is a quick tip, but an important one:

If you want to create impactful action shots, it's important that you zoom your lens (or physically move) until the subject fills the frame.

In other words, don't leave a lot of background. Your subject is the most important part of the composition, so they should dominate. You don't want to leave room for major distractions.

(The one exception is if you're aiming to create an environmental, scene-setting shot; in these situations, it can help to zoom out to capture the entire area.)

10. Wait for peak action

Once the action begins, you may be tempted to start holding down the shutter button so you don't miss any critical moments.

But while this can be a successful method of capturing action, I prefer to take a more deliberate approach. Instead of machine-gunning my camera, I set my camera to its continuous shooting mode , then I anticipate moments of peak action.

When the action arrives, I quickly capture a burst of 2-4 shots, then I recompose. I wait for more action, and when something else of interest happens, I'll take another burst, and so on.

These days, camera burst modes are so fast that – if you're not choosy in your shooting approach – you can easily fire off hundreds or even thousands of shots in a couple of minutes, which will be a pain to sort through later.

11. Use a monopod

When you're on the sidelines of an indoor sports event, camera in hand, ready to capture every thrilling moment, stability is key. But here's the catch: a tripod might be too bulky or simply not allowed. That's where a monopod comes in.

Think of a monopod as your portable stabilizing buddy. It's like a tripod, but with just one leg. This simplicity is its strength. A monopod gives you that essential stability for crisp shots, without the bulk. It's easy to carry around, quick to set up, and doesn't take up much space.

Now, you might wonder, how do you pick a good monopod? Look for one that's sturdy yet lightweight. Adjustable height is crucial, as it allows you to quickly adapt to different shooting angles. And don't worry about the cost; monopods are generally quite affordable.

12. Don't ignore breaks in the action

It may seem odd, but breaks in the action are often great times to take some photos.

By “break in the action,” I'm referring to two times:

  1. A momentary pause during the event. For example, after a difficult gymnastic move, there is typically a momentary pose. The same holds true in singing and dancing; the performers often hold a pose after finishing a part of the routine. This pose often makes for a great shot – plus, since the subjects are frozen, you won't have as big an issue with blur.
  2. An actual break, like the end of a period in sports. During these breaks, there are often warm-up drills that lend themselves to great shots. And you're typically allowed a bit more latitude in terms of your own movements, so you can potentially walk around and find some interesting angles.最好的部分？ Even if you shoot during a break, no one will know whether you took the shot during a drill or the real game/match/meet. In fact, after a year or two, you probably won't remember, either!

13. Nail the focus

Because you are shooting with your aperture wide open, you'll have a very shallow depth of field. That means the focus will be unforgiving, and if you miss it, there will be no leeway.

So what should you focus on? Well, the subject, of course! If your subject is a person, then always focus on the eyes. If the eyes are on different planes, focus on the nearest eye.

This is why it pays to be comfortable with your camera's autofocus modes . Your camera will have a mode designed to focus on stationary points (Canon calls this One-Shot and Nikon and Sony call it AF-S). Your camera will have another autofocus mode designed to track moving subjects (Canon calls this AI Servo and Nikon and Sony call it AF-C). In the case of a moving subject, this mode will continuously track your initial focus point and readjust as it moves. Most photographers use this mode in the case of a subject that is moving. I personally almost always use the stationary autofocus, but use whichever one you are comfortable with!

Another decision you should make to help with your focusing is whether to use back-button focus . Normally, your camera focuses when you press your shutter button halfway down. You can, however, set your camera to focus when you press a button on the back of the camera instead. I prefer this method because the focus will not automatically reset with each picture. Either way is fine, but back-button focus gives you slightly more control over your camera's focus, so you might want to give it a try.

14. Chimp!

That's right, I want you to chimp . This refers to the act of looking at your photos on the camera's LCD screen.

Some photographers look down on this practice and referred to it as chimping (supposedly because the people looking at the LCD make “ooh, ooh!” noises while looking at their pictures, similar to chimpanzees). I actually think you should look at your LCD in any shooting context, but in this situation, it is especially important to do so.

There is just too much that can go wrong, and you need to make sure you're getting the shots. You might have the exposure wrong, your focus might be off, the action might be too fast for your shutter speed, and so on. You don't want to get home and discover you were doing something wrong that could have been corrected while you were shooting.

15. Add some noise reduction

You will have your own workflow for post-processing your pictures, so I won't dwell on that too much here. There are a few things, however, that are particularly important in this context and that I want to pass along.

The first is that you will need to do some noise reduction ; you'll be using high ISOs for these shots, and you should probably do it in a manner that is a little different than you are used to.

Start off by using Lightroom's noise reduction in the usual manner. Push the Luminance slider to the right. (There is an equivalent slider in Adobe Camera Raw if you use Photoshop or Photoshop Elements.) Keep the increase moderate at this point, usually in the range of 10-15.

After that, reduce the noise in the background further. The background of your picture will usually be blurry because you used a large aperture, so the loss of detail from the additional noise reduction will not hurt anything. In Lightroom, use the Brush and paint the noise reduction selectively. You can do the same in Adobe Camera Raw, or you can head into Photoshop, create a new layer with noise reduction, and mask the subject.

16. Sharpen the subject

Next, sharpen your photo , but not all at once; instead, like the noise reduction discussed above, you should tailor it to the image. To start off, apply a slight amount of sharpening to the whole file.

Then apply sharpening to the subject only. In Lightroom, use the Brush again. This time increase the Clarity and Sharpening amounts. Apply the effect only to your subject, while leaving the background alone.

You can do the same thing in Adobe Camera Raw, or you can take the file into Photoshop, create a new layer , sharpen the layer, then mask out everything but your subject. The extra sharpening will help make your subject stand out a little bit better, and it'll also emphasize the tension produced by the action.

Action photography in bad light: final words

Photographing action in low light is a severe test of your camera equipment and your photography skills. It pays to have fast glass and a camera that performs well in low light, but gear isn't everything!

Using the tips in this article, you should be able to set up your camera and create the proper exposure settings. It will take practice to consistently nail the focus, but once you get really good, you'll be unstoppable!

What is shutter speed in photography, and how can you use it to create stunning photos?

Shutter speed is a foundational photographic concept – one that every beginner photographer must master. Once you know how to use shutter speed, you'll be able to capture sharp photos at will. You'll also be prepared to capture interesting artistic effects (such as slow shutter speed blur).

In this article, I'm going to take you through all the shutter speed basics, including:

  • A simple definition of shutter speed
  • The effects that shutter speed has on your images
  • The difference (and importance) of slow versus fast shutter speeds
  • How to use different shutter speeds for outstanding results
  • How to have fun with creative shutter speed techniques

So if you're ready to become a shutter speed photography expert, then let's dive right in!

What is shutter speed?

Shutter speed is the length of time the camera shutter is open while the camera takes a photo.

You press the shutter button, the shutter opens for a predetermined time period (ie, the shutter speed), then the shutter closes and the image is complete.

When the shutter is open, light hits the camera sensor; therefore, the longer the shutter speed, the more light the sensor receives. This has various effects, as discussed in the next section.

Note that shutter speed is measured in seconds (or fractions of a second). Here are a few common shutter speeds:

  • 10秒
  • 1秒
  • 1/10s
  • 1/30秒
  • 1/60秒
  • 1/125秒
  • 1/250秒
  • 1/500秒
  • 1/1000s
  • 1/1600s
  • 1/2000秒

The list begins with a long, 10-second shutter speed, but the shutter speeds get shorter and shorter, ending with a lightning-fast 1/2000s shutter speed.

Note that the shutter speed measurements listed above certainly aren't comprehensive. Most DSLRs and mirrorless cameras let you select from 30-second shutter speeds all the way down to 1/4000s or 1/8000s, though you may also have access to a special mode – called Bulb mode – that lets you keep the shutter button open for your desired length of time.

Therefore, while most cameras offer several dozen basic shutter speed options (shutter speed presets , if you will), there are literally thousands of possible shutter speeds you can use, all of which expose the camera sensor to slightly different quantities of light.合理？

How shutter speed affects your photos

Shutter speed impacts your images in two key ways:

  1. It increases and decreases exposure (ie, image brightness)
  2. It increases and decreases sharpness (ie, image detail)

Let's take a look at each item in turn.

Shutter speed increases and decreases exposure

The longer the shutter speed, the more light that hits your camera sensor – and the brighter the image becomes .

So if you photograph a tree at 1/1000s, then you lower the shutter speed to 1s, your second image – with its slower shutter speed – will be noticeably brighter.

This has major consequences. Much of photography is about achieving the proper brightness, or exposure , for a scene, and by adjusting the shutter speed, you can get different results. For this reason, shutter speed is one of the three camera exposure variables (along with aperture and ISO ).

So when you're out with your camera, you'll need to adjust the shutter speed to achieve a nice, balanced exposure. The specifics will depend on the scene, but watch for blown-out highlights and clipped shadows. In other words, make sure you don't over or underexpose so heavily that you lose information in the lightest or darkest parts of the photo.

Shutter speed increases and decreases sharpness

Faster shutter speeds freeze motion. Slower shutter speeds blur motion.

So if you're photographing a bird in flight at 1/4000s, every feather will be crisp, even the flapping wings. But if you photograph that same bird at 1/15s, it will be an indecipherable blur.

Now, the shutter speed needed to freeze motion will change depending on the speed of the moving object. A feather drifting through the air may require a 1/200s shutter speed for maximum sharpness, while a fast-moving car may require 1/2000s or more.

A too-slow shutter speed is one of the main reasons why pictures come out blurry – so you should pay very close attention to your shutter speed value. Always make sure it's fast enough to get the results you're after.

How to set the shutter speed on your camera

The precise shutter speed mechanisms vary from camera to camera – but changing the shutter speed is usually as simple as rotating a dial (to learn all the specifics, I recommend you check your camera manual).

Note that your ability to adjust the shutter speed will change depending on your camera mode.

If you use Auto mode, your camera will select the shutter speed for you, and you will have zero ability to make changes.

If you use Manual mode , you can dial in the shutter speed at will (and you can also independently select your aperture and ISO).

If you use Shutter Priority mode , you can select the shutter speed and the ISO, while your camera will select the aperture for the optimal exposure (based on its evaluation of the scene).

If you use Aperture Priority mode, you can select the aperture and ISO, while your camera will select the shutter speed for an optimal exposure (again, based on its evaluation of the scene).

Different camera modes are good for different situations, so don't just pick a mode and stick to it; instead, learn to adjust your mode dial depending on your photographic needs.

How does shutter speed relate to ISO and aperture?

In a previous section, I mentioned ISO and aperture, and how they – along with shutter speed – affect image exposure. But how exactly does this work?

First of all, shutter speed, aperture, and ISO are all part of the exposure triangle because they together determine the amount of light that enters your camera. Each of these factors complements each other in that you can achieve similar exposure outcomes by adjusting the variables in relation to one another.

You may be familiar with the term “stops,” which refers to a halving (or a doubling) of the amount of light hitting the camera sensor. Therefore, with every full stop of adjustment in shutter speed, you are either doubling or halving the amount of light that enters your camera.

This means a shutter speed of 1/250s is twice as fast and lets in half the amount of light as a 1/125s shutter speed. And a shutter speed of 1/60s is approximately twice as slow as 1/125s and therefore lets in double the amount of light. So, 1/250s is one stop faster than 1/125s and two stops faster than 1/60s.

What does that have to do with aperture and ISO? The connection comes into play when you realize that ISO and aperture are also measured in stops, albeit in slightly different ways. This means that we can directly relate shutter speed to our ISO and aperture.

Let's say we are shooting a moving subject at 1/60s at f/5.6 and ISO 100. The image is exposed correctly, but the subject is blurred. We find that a shutter speed of 1/250s (two stops faster) will freeze the motion, but it also leaves our scene underexposed by two stops since we have effectively decreased the amount of light by a factor of four.

To maintain our exposure, we must somehow compensate for the reduced amount of light from the faster shutter speed. We have two options: we can either increase the ISO by two stops or shoot with an aperture that is two stops wider than f/5.6.

So our new exposure settings would be either 1/250s at f/2.8 and ISO 100, or 1/250s at f/5.6 and ISO 400. Make sense?

How to choose the perfect shutter speed: step by step

Struggling to pick the perfect shutter speed?你不是一个人。

But while selecting the best shutter speed for your shooting situation might seem hard, it's actually easy – once you get the hang of it. Here's the two-step process I recommend:

Step 1: Determine the lowest-possible shutter speed that will get you a sharp shot

Look at your scene. Ask yourself: Are any subjects moving ? And if so, what shutter speed do I need to freeze them?

You'll get better at determining the lowest-possible shutter speed over time, but at first, it will take a lot of trial and error. Here's a list of minimum sharp shutter speeds to get you started:

  • Water flowing: 1/125s
  • People walking: 1/250s
  • People/animals running: 1/500s
  • Cars driving: 1/1000s
  • Birds flying: 1/2000s

Also note that, if your scene has zero movement, you cannot simply select whatever shutter speed you like. If you're handholding your camera, then your hands will shake, and this will create blur – unless your shutter speed is fast enough.

The lowest-possible handheld shutter speed varies from person to person, plus it depends on your lens (longer lenses increase camera shake). And thanks to image stabilization technology, some cameras and lenses allow for slower handheld shooting. But I'd recommend keeping the shutter speed above 1/60s or so for short lenses, and 1/160s or so for long lenses, at least until you've done some tests.

Of course, if you're shooting a scene with no movement, you do have another option: you can shoot with a tripod. Assuming your tripod is sturdy, it will let you drop your shutter speed as low as you like (which is how you can create beautiful moving water effects, as I discuss later in this article!).

Step 2: Boost your shutter speed (or adjust other variables) for the proper exposure

At this point, you should know your minimum shutter speed for a sharp shot. You shouldn't drop below this speed – but you can always go above it, depending on your exposure needs.

If you're in Manual mode, check your camera's exposure bar (in the viewfinder). If the scene is overexposed, go ahead and boost the shutter speed.

If you're in Shutter Priority mode, your camera will automatically select an aperture for a good exposure. But feel free to raise the shutter speed as long as your camera continues to choose an aperture you like.

On the other hand, if the scene is underexposed according to your camera's exposure bar, you'll need to change other camera settings to get the right exposure. Consider widening the aperture – but if this isn't possible, you'll need to raise the ISO.

Do not drop the shutter speed, however. Better to increase the ISO for a noisy image than to end up with unwanted blur.

就是这样！ To recap: Start by identifying your lowest-possible shutter speed for a sharp shot, then simply make tweaks for the optimal exposure.

That way, you get a crisp photo – with a balanced exposure, too.

Slow shutter speed photography

The advice I've given above is perfect for situations where you want to freeze a moving subject.

But what if a sharp shot isn't your goal? What if, instead, you want to creatively blur your photo for a beautiful effect?

You see, blur isn't always bad; it can communicate motion, plus it can look truly breathtaking, as in this waterfall shot:

In deliberate motion-blur situations, you should set your camera to Manual mode, then dial in the exact shutter speed you're after.

At this point, you should check your camera's exposure bar and adjust the aperture and/or ISO for a good exposure.

Note that you definitely need a tripod for this type of long-exposure photography. Otherwise, the entire shot will blur!

Pro tip: If you're struggling to get a slow enough shutter speed without overexposing the image, consider using a neutral density filter , which blocks out light and is perfect for long exposure shooting . It's commonly used to create long-exposure images in bright conditions.

What shutter speed is best? Basic recommendations

Now that you're familiar with the ins and outs of selecting a shutter speed, I'd like to share a few basic recommendations for selecting the right shutter speed. These recommendations won't always work, but they should certainly offer you a good starting point when adjusting your camera settings.

The best shutter speeds for landscape photography

Landscape photographers generally have two shutter-related goals:

  1. Get the image sharp from foreground to background
  2. Create artistic motion blur in moving water and clouds

Now, foreground-to-background sharpness refers to a deep depth of field . And while this isn't directly related to shutter speed, the longer the shutter speed, the easier it becomes to achieve a deep depth of field.

(Why? The depth of field is controlled by the aperture – and lengthier shutter speeds allow you to adjust the aperture without underexposing the scene.)

Plus, as I explained in a previous section, if you want artistic motion blur, you need to lengthen the shutter speed.

Bottom line: Landscape photography thrives on long exposures. Most landscape photographers shoot at 1s to 1/200s in bright daylight, and as the light falls, the shutter speeds slow. Many landscape shooters work at 1/30s to 30s (or more) around sunrise, sunset, and at night.

Such lengthy shutter speeds are only possible with a tripod. If you don't have a tripod, then it's often best to drop your shutter speed as low as you can go without creating camera shake (often around 1/60s or so).

The best shutter speeds for portrait photography

Portrait photographers can be pretty flexible when choosing shutter speeds. The key goal is to keep your shots sharp – by avoiding camera shake as well as motion blur – but because you can generally instruct your subject and work from a stable position, this shouldn't be too tough.

If you're shooting a stationary subject, feel free to drop your shutter speed to around 1/80s or so (though 1/200s is safer).

And if you're shooting a moving subject, such as a person dancing, I'd recommend working at 1/500s and beyond.

The best shutter speeds for wildlife and bird photography

Bird and wildlife photography generally involves capturing fast-moving subjects with long lenses.

Therefore, you should generally use the fastest shutter speed you can get away with. For slower-moving animals, 1/500s is a reasonable starting point (and you can go lower if the animal is completely stationary – just make sure you keep your lens on a tripod or handheld as stably as possible).

For fast-moving animals and birds, 1/1000s is the place to start. And when action is occurring, I'd really recommend pushing your shutter speed to 1/2000s and beyond.

The best shutter speeds for street photography

Street photographers tend to be less concerned with sharpness than other shooters, so your choice of shutter speed isn't nearly as important.

That said, if you're walking while shooting and/or photographing walking people, 1/250s is a safe starting point. If both you and your subject are stationary, then you can often shoot at 1/100s or slower (assuming you're using good handholding techniques and relatively short lenses).

Tips and ideas for using your shutter speed creatively

The reason I'm a big fan of experimenting with different shutter speeds is that the opportunities seem endless. By only using a fast shutter speed you'll limit your photography and miss out on so many great images. In my opinion, shutter speed is the setting that allows you to be the most creative and to capture unique and visually interesting images.

By changing the shutter speed only slightly (eg, from 1/120s to 1/60s), the image can look completely different and tell a whole different story. Here are just a few ideas and techniques for using shutter speed creatively:

1. Use a fast shutter speed to freeze motion

In times of high action or drama, you can stop the motion by using a very fast shutter speed.

To do this, you will want your shutter speed to be at least 1/250s. As with the picture below of the water droplets being flipped through the air, you may want your shutter speed to be significantly faster. (The image displayed below was shot at 1/8000s!)

Working with shutter speeds this fast, even on bright sunny days, will require some adjustments. For example, you'll need to open up the aperture to its widest setting. (This will result in a shallow depth of field, but such an effect generally looks good in action photos!) You will also probably need to increase the ISO (a little on bright days, a lot on cloudy days or indoors).

One more tip for this type of fast-shutter-speed photo: learn to anticipate the shot. With the continuous shooting speeds offered by most modern cameras, you may be tempted to just hold the shutter button down and blast away – but in my experience, this rarely works. The perfect moment is usually only captured by anticipating the action and triggering the shutter at precisely the right moment.

2. Pan for a cool slow-motion effect

Another way to use shutter speed creatively in times of action is to pan. Panning is where you move the camera during the exposure to follow the subject. Done properly, the subject will turn out relatively sharp, while the background will be blurred to convey a sense of motion.

Panning should generally done at slow shutter speeds (between 1/8s and 1/30s). Being able to slow down the shutter speed is typically welcome news, as it will mean you do not have to crank up your ISO or make other offsetting moves. But getting a good result when panning will frequently require at least a few attempts while you adjust the speed and other settings.

3. Slow the shutter speed way down

The next creative use of shutter speed I'd like to cover here is long exposure. This is where you hold the shutter open for a time and allow certain parts of your picture to move through the frame. You will always need a tripod for this technique.

Long exposure shutter speeds are basically between 10 and 30 seconds. Most cameras offer you the ability to go even longer by using Bulb mode, where the shutter stays open as long as you hold the shutter button down. A remote shutter release, which is always a good idea when you are shooting from a tripod, is almost a necessity for this type of shot.

Long exposure is a great technique whenever there is moving water involved, such as coastal scenes , rivers, and waterfalls . It is also great for light trail photography.

Most of the time, your challenge with shutter speed is to get enough light into the camera for a fast shutter speed, but when doing slow-shutter photography, you're usually faced with the opposite problem. The challenge is to limit the amount of light entering the camera so that you can leave the shutter open for a long time without overexposing the image.

To do that, first close down the aperture to its smallest setting and use the lowest ISO setting on your camera. If those moves don't restrict the light enough, you will need to use a neutral density filter. These are filters that restrict the amount of light coming into your camera.

They come in different strengths, though the typical values are between 2 and 10 stops of light. Get one of these ND filters (or a few different ND filters with different strengths) and keep it in your bag if you think you might like to try the slow-shutter-speed approach.

4. Create blur with deliberate movement

One of the main reasons for using a tripod when photographing with a slow shutter speed is to remove any vibration and movement from the camera, leading to crisp and sharp images. This shutter speed technique, however, goes against those guidelines; instead of leaving the camera on a steady tripod, you're going to tilt or pan it while taking the image.

The use of a tripod is not necessary for this technique, and it's easy to do without one. If you're using a shutter speed slower than one second, a tripod can help you achieve a better result, though.

You'll get the best results when your subject contains different colors and also has texture and patterns. When you've found the subject you wish to photograph – let's say a treeline or a patch of grass – slow your shutter speed down to between 1/15s and 1/4s of a second. You can use an even slower shutter speed, but I've found that the best results are in this range, as you'll still get some good texture and detail in the image.

Now, when you press the shutter button, quickly tilt or pan the camera in one direction – make sure that you're quick enough! As you can see, the result is an abstract image with lots of lines. This technique doesn't work for all scenes, and I recommend zooming in on your subject to avoid including the sky.

Continue repeating this technique and try moving the camera at various speeds; you can also make small changes to the shutter speed setting. You'll soon see that even small adjustments will have a huge impact on the final image. It may take quite a few attempts before you get an image you're truly satisfied with, so keep playing.

5. Try the zoom-blur technique

This is a technique you can experiment with heavily as the results will vary widely.它的工作原理如下：

Set your shutter speed to five seconds and place the camera on a tripod. Press the shutter button, wait two seconds, then slowly start zooming your lens. Continue until the exposure is completed.

The resulting file will often appear as if two images are combined into one. The background will often be sharp, while ghost-like lines will create a sense of motion and can add a lot of extra depth.

Again, as with all of these creative exercises, trial and error is your friend. Don't just do it once and move on. Try it multiple times with different settings, vary the exposure, try a different zoom speed (go fast, then slow), zoom in then out, zoom and stop at varying intervals, etc. After a while, you'll hopefully capture something that has potential!

The shutter speed cheat sheet

To take your photography to the next level and achieve perfectly exposed photos, it's important to understand and master shutter speed. Whether you're looking to improve your understanding of shutter speed as part of the exposure triangle or you want to know how to use it artistically, the shutter speed ceat sheet makes things much easier!

Shutter speed in photography: final words

Now that you've finished this article, you're well-equipped to create some gorgeous photos.

So head out with your camera and test out different shutter speeds. Get familiar with your options. And try the tips and techniques outlined above!

Shutter speed FAQ

What is the best shutter speed?

Fast-moving subjects shot with long lenses require a short shutter speed (such as 1/250s or higher). But you can get sharp shots of stationary subjects shot with short lenses at 1/60s to 1/200s. And if you have a tripod, you can go even slower!

What is the shutter speed in a camera?

The shutter speed refers to the length of time the shutter is open when you press the shutter button. The longer the shutter is open, the more light that hits the sensor, and the brighter the image becomes.

What is a fast shutter speed?

Shutter speeds around 1/1000s and above are fast, while shutter speeds in the 1/100s to 1/1000s range are average, and shutter speeds from 1/100s on down are slow.

Is a higher shutter speed better?

A higher shutter speed helps guarantee a sharp photo. However, if your subject isn't moving, a high shutter speed can be overkill (and it will decrease the image exposure, which can be a problem). Also, a slower shutter speed can create artistic effects (such as blurry water).

What is a safe shutter speed?

A basic safe shutter speed is 1/250s, which will let you capture sharp shots of stationary and slow-moving subjects. But if you're photographing cars driving, birds in flight, or other fast action, you'll generally need to shoot at 1/1000s or above.

Black and white landscape photography is beautiful, timeless, and – when done well – incredibly moving. But how can you capture stunning B&W landscapes? How can you find the right compositions, choose the right camera settings, and do the right post-processing so that you end up with truly breathtaking images?
